docs.lead_paragraph: A 13-month-old boy has become the first infant in the United States to have a faulty heart valve replaced with a valve from a cow, officials at an Indiana hospital said today. The boy, Ryan Doty, was in fair condition after the May 4 surgery, said Shannon Shaw, spokeswoman for Riley Hospital for Children.

headline.main: Cow Valve Used In Heart of Boy

docs.abstract: Thirteen-month-old Ryan Doty becomes first infant in United States to have faulty heart valve replaced with a valve from a cow; is in fair condition at Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Now that people and pets are spending more time outdoors, the incidence of dog bites is about to soar, which is why the Humane Society of the United States in conjunction with other concerned agencies is once again urging the public to learn how to act around dogs and what to do to prevent dog bites. The statistics are cause for concern. Each year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates, 4.7 million people are bitten by dogs, 800,000 of them badly enough to require medical treatment. At least 60 percent of dog bites and 72 percent of fatal bites involve children. Half of all children in this country are bitten by a dog before their 12th birthday. And since children are most often bitten on the face, many need plastic surgery to minimize unsightly scars.

headline.main: Heeding the Warnings From Dangerous Dogs

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on how to act around dogs to prevent being bitten; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study finds that giving children a decongestant does nothing to ease the earaches they often suffer during takeoffs and landings, or, indirectly, the headaches that some neighboring passengers sustain from the crying that follows. The news, unwelcome at any time of year, comes as many families prepare to take airplane flights long and short over the summer vacation season. The study appears this month in The Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine, published by the American Medical Association.

headline.main: Decongestant Is Found Useless for Young Fliers' Earaches

docs.abstract: New study finds that giving children a decongestant does nothing to ease earaches they often suffer during airplane takeoffs and landings; suggests that parents give child something to stimulate swallowing on ascent and descent (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Things may still go ''bump'' in the night, but school-age children are actually more afraid of sharks and snakes, according to an Ohio State University study examining children's fears and anxieties. The study involved 90 boys and girls 8 to 12 years old and included interviews with the children, human-figure drawing analysis and questionnaires gauging anxiety.

headline.main: What Fills a Child's Garden of Fears

docs.abstract: Ohio State University researchers study children's fears and anxieties; over all, children report 177 fears, and neither sex appears to be generally more fearful than the other; children were most often afraid for their safety, of animals or of natural phenomenon like storms, lightning or thunder (S)
docs.snippet: Things may still go ''bump'' in the night, but school-age children are actually more afraid of sharks and snakes, according to an Ohio State University study examining children's fears and anxieties.    The study involved 90 boys and girls 8 to 12...

docs.lead_paragraph: Teen-agers who are gay or bisexual are more than three times as likely to attempt suicide as other youth, according to a Massachusetts study reported this month in The Archives of Pediatric and Adolescent Medicine. Young men are at particular risk, the report found. The lead researcher, Dr. Robert Garofalo, a pediatrician at Children's Hospital at the Harvard Medical School, also noted that these young people were more likely to engage in other high risk behaviors: alcohol consumption, drug and tobacco use and sexual activities with multiple partners. ''Any clinician who works with youth has long suspected that attempting suicide is an issue for a subset of gay youth,'' Dr. Garofalo said. ''I see the results of this study as a cry for help.''

headline.main: From Gay Teen-Agers, a Cry for Help

docs.abstract: Massachusetts study finds that teen-agers who are gay or bisexual are more than three times as likely to attempt suicide as other youth (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Margaret Tracey floated across the Lincoln Center stage on Sunday afternoon, every line of a perfectly fit ballerina's body where every line ought to be, it was impossible to believe that little more than six months ago she was, as grandmother used to say, great with child. Ms. Tracey, 32, a principal with the New York City Ballet, gave birth to a son, Avery, on Oct. 22. Her friend Stacey Calvert, a 36-year-old soloist with the company, gave birth to a girl, Ayla, two weeks later. This month, both ballerinas had their post-baby debuts, and the experience makes it clear that it is far easier to get in great shape soon after pregnancy or other disruptive events if one was in great shape to begin with.

headline.main: A Leap From Childbirth to Ballet Stage

docs.abstract: Comment on exercise regimen that helps new mothers get back into shape; ballet dancers who have used regimen comment; photos (M)
